title: Savers reject the high life despite pension freedoms
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Aug 31, 2015, 06:13 BST - UK Markets closed for Summer Bank holiday Savers reject the high life despite pension freedoms By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 5 hours ago Print 
Fears that savers would blow their pension pots on Lamborghinis appear unfounded, as over-55s keep their money safe 
A tiny minority of over-55s have accessed their pension pots, despite new rules giving them more freedom to spend their life savings as they wish. 
Only 9pc of those eligible to access the funds have done so, according to a study from pensions and investments firm Zurich, as most are still considering their options and do not want to crack open the piggy bank just yet. 
Chancellor George Osborne scrapped the requirement for pensioners to buy an annuity , which pay a low income to savers when interest rates are at rock bottom, and instead choose what to do with their money. 
However, those who take out large amounts of cash will end up paying a higher rate of tax on the lump sums . 
At the time the change in the rules was announced in 2014, the then-pensions minister Steve Webb fuelled concerns of pensioners splurging their cash and having nothing left to live on when he said “if people do get a Lamborghini, and end up on the state pension, the state is much less concerned about that, and that is their choice.” 
While Mr Webb was happy with the new freedoms, critics such as then-shadow Chancellor Ed Balls warned that pensioners could end up making the “wrong choices” due to a lack of financial know-how and a sudden discovery that they could access large sums at once. 
However, Zurich’s survey has indeed found that most people who can benefit from the changes have not reacted with a spending spree. 
Of the 91pc who have not accessed their pension pots, just under one-third have ever looked at their options. Of those, 54pc said they are not ready to make a decision yet, while 34pc are keeping their pensions invested and spending other assets like cash savings before they need to access the long-term pots. 
A further 18pc are worried that if they do draw funds down from the pension pot, they could run out of money . 
“Most of those keeping their pensions intact aren’t ready to make a decision or are spending other savings first. Far from rushing to cash in their pots, many Britons seem prepared to use their pensions as they were intended - to provide an income through retirement,” said Zurich UK Life’s chief executive Gary Shaughnessy. 
However, he also said that excessive caution could lead to some savers missing out, if they fail to consider their options fully. 
“Almost 70pc of over-55s have yet to explore how they could benefit from the reforms. By engaging early with the new freedoms, savers can make more informed decisions on their retirement.”
